meanings.definition: To graft by uniting a growing branch to a stock without separating the branch from its parent plant.
meanings.sent1: I will inarch this branch onto the tree to help it grow stronger.
meanings.sent2: The gardener will inarch the rose bush to create a hybrid plant.
meanings.sent3: Trying to inarch a banana onto an apple tree would be quite a fruity experiment.
meanings.sent4: She inarched her ideas seamlessly into the existing project.
meanings.sent5: The act of inarching symbolizes the bond between nature and nurture.

meanings.definition: To unite by grafting a growing branch to a stock without separating the branch from its parent plant.
meanings.sent1: The farmer will inarch the apple tree to improve its fruit quality.
meanings.sent2: Inarching is a common technique used in horticulture to create new plant varieties.
meanings.sent3: The squirrel tried to inarch a pinecone onto the oak tree, thinking it was a nut.
meanings.sent4: Their friendship inarched their hearts together, creating a strong bond.
meanings.sent5: The artist's brush inarched colors on the canvas, blending them harmoniously.
